channel.title: Yahoo Sports - Tennis News
channel.description: Latest news and information about the Tennis.

item.media:text: Novak Djokovic, of Serbia, returns a shot to Nick Kyrgios, of Australia, at the BNP Paribas Open tennis tournament, Wednesday, March 15, 2017, in Indian Wells, Calif. (AP Photo/Mark J. Terrill)
item.title: Djokovic says elbow healed, looking to return to competition (Yahoo Sports)
item.description: With his elbow better and his body rested, Novak Djokovic is ready to get back on court when Serbia faces Spain in the Davis Cup quarterfinals. ''I haven't had too many matches recently, and that's what I need to get back in shape,'' Djokovic said Tuesday. ''I skipped Miami and I haven't done much in Indian Wells, so the start of the season wasn't ideal,'' Djokovic said.

item.media:text: Mirjana Lucic-Baroni, of Croatia, hits a return to Carolina Pliskova during the Miami Open tennis tournament, Tuesday, March 28, 2017, in Key Biscayne, Fla. Pliskova won 6-3, 6-4. (AP Photo/Lynne Sladky)
item.title: S Rogers outlasts Veronica Cepede Royg at Volvo Open (Yahoo Sports)
item.description: CHARLESTON, S.C. (AP) -- The expressions just kept changing on the face of Shelby Rogers as the American tried to figure out the winning moves against Veronica Cepede Royg at the Volvo Car Open.

item.media:text: Bill Gates, right, and Warren Buffett talk during a break in the FEI World Cup equestrian jumping grand prix in Omaha, Neb., Saturday, April 1, 2017. Jennifer Gates, daughter of Bill Gates, is one of the contestants. (AP Photo/Nati Harnik)
item.title: Roger Federer, Microsoft's Gates to play doubles for charity (Yahoo Sports)
item.description: SEATTLE (AP) -- How's this for a doubles team? Roger Federer and Bill Gates.

item.media:text: Johanna Konta, of Britain, returns a shot from Caroline Wozniacki, of Denmark, during the women's singles final tennis match at the Miami Open, Saturday, April 1, 2017 in Key Biscayne, Fla. (AP Photo/Wilfredo Lee)
item.title: Sore shoulder knocks Johanna Konta from Charleston tourney (Yahoo Sports)
item.description: Playing her first match on clay in almost a year, Jelena Jankovic felt right at home on Daniel Island. Making her 13th career appearance in Charleston after missing the tournament last year, Jankovic won the first seven games, breaking serve six times, to take control of her match against Ekaterina Alexandrova in a 6-0, 6-4 victory Monday on the first round of the Volvo Car Open. The Russian arrived in Charleston on a 10-match winning streak on the ITF Circuit, which had boosted her to a career-high ranking of No.86.

item.media:text: Roger Federer, of Switzerland, holds up his trophy after defeating Rafael Nadal, of Spain, during the men's singles final tennis match at the Miami Open, Sunday, April 2, 2017 in Key Biscayne, Fla. (AP Photo/Wilfredo Lee)
item.title: Federer beats Nadal 6-3, 6-4 in Miami Open final (Yahoo Sports)
item.description: Weary from three months of winning, Roger Federer hit one last shot Sunday, whacking a celebratory forehand into the stands to punctuate his victory over Rafael Nadal in the Miami Open final. ''I'm not 24 anymore,'' Federer said. At 35, Federer is playing some of the best tennis of his career - so good he's even dominating his longtime nemesis.

item.media:text: Roger Federer, of Switzerland, serves to Tomas Berdych, of the Czech Republic, at the Miami Open tennis tournament, Thursday, March 30, 2017, in Key Biscayne, Fla. Federer defeated Berdych 6-2, 3-6, 7-6 (6). (AP Photo/Wilfredo Lee)
item.title: (Less) quiet, please? Federer doesn't mind some crowd noise (Yahoo Sports)
item.description: Roger Federer is not bothered by a little noise when he plays. After the No. 4 seed rallied to beat No. 10 Tomas Berdych in the quarterfinals of the Miami Open on Thursday - a down-to-the-wire three-setter where the crowd was clearly pulling for Federer - tennis' all-time Grand Slam king was asked about the longstanding tradition calling for fans to be as quiet as possible during points. Winners from Federer, and even errors from Berdych, drew loud roars.

item.title: Pro tennis gets structural shake-up following ITF review (Yahoo Sports)
item.description: The number of players competing in professional tennis events will reduce drastically following a major structural shake-up aimed at helping more competitors earn a living and improving the pathway from junior level to the top of the sport. The International Tennis Federation undertook a three-year review of the professional and junior game, which established that there are too many players trying to compete on the professional circuit, too few players breaking even and that the age of these players is increasing.

item.media:text: Jeremy Chardy, of France, returns a shot from Marin Cilic, of Croatia, at the Miami Open, Friday, March 24, 2017 in Key Biscayne, Fla. (AP Photo/Wilfredo Lee)
item.title: Injured Monfils to miss France's Davis Cup quarterfinal (Yahoo Sports)
item.description: Gael Monfils has withdrawn from France's Davis Cup quarterfinal against Britain next month because of injuries to his left knee and Achilles tendon. The French tennis federation said in a statement on Wednesday that Pierre-Hugues Herbert was also ruled out of the clay-court series in Rouen from April 7-9 because of a right thigh injury. France captain Yannick Noah called up Julien Benneteau and Jeremy Chardy to replace them in his squad.

item.media:text: Rafael Nadal, of Spain, returns the ball to Philipp Kohlschreiber, of Germany, during the Miami Open tennis tournament, Sunday, March 26, 2017, in Key Biscayne, Fla. Nadal won 0-6, 6-2, 6-3. (AP Photo/Luis M. Alvarez)
item.title: Djokovic in, Nadal out for Serbia-Spain Davis Cup (Yahoo Sports)
item.description: Rafael Nadal will miss Spain's Davis Cup quarterfinal against Serbia and the chance to take on Novak Djokovic in Belgrade next month. Nadal, the 14-time Grand Slam champion, was not in the team announced by Spain captain Conchita Martinez on Tuesday.

item.media:text: Johanna Konta, of Britain, reacts after defeating Caroline Wozniacki, of Denmark, 6-4, 6-3, in the women's singles final tennis match at the Miami Open, Saturday, April 1, 2017 in Key Biscayne, Fla. (AP Photo/Wilfredo Lee)
item.title: Brit Johanna Konta beats Wozniacki in Miami Open final (Yahoo Sports)
item.description: Johanna Konta lofted a lob off the baseline for a winner on championship point, waited for instant replay to confirm the call and even then hesitated to celebrate the biggest title of her 11-year career. Seeded 10th, Konta was an unlikely champion, but the Australian-born Briton beat Caroline Wozniacki 6-4, 6-3 in Saturday's final at the Miami Open. Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer renew their rivalry where it began in the men's final Sunday.
